text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on January 13 in history.
1691 - George Fox, British founder of the Society of Friends, or Quakers, died.
1842 - At the end of an attempted retreat from Kabul, a British force of 9,000 men was massacred in the Khyber Pass.
1864 - Stephen Foster, American composer of songs such as "Swanee River", died.
1884 - Sophie Tucker, American entertainer known as "the last of the red hot mamas", born in Russia as Sophie Abuza.
1886 - The Gold Coast in Africa was separated into the two colonies of Lagos and the Gold Coast.
1893 - The British Labour Party was founded with Keir Hardie as its leader.
1898 - French author Emile Zola published his "J'Accuse" letter, accusing the French government of a cover-up in the Alfred Dreyfus treason case.
1910 - New York's Metropolitan Opera took part in the first live radio broadcast of opera, presenting "Pagliacci" and "Cavelleria Rusticana".
1915 - South African troops under Louis Botha occupied Swakopmund in German South West Africa.
1915 - The town of Avezzano in central Italy was struck by a huge earthquake in which 30,000 people died.
1919 - U.S. film actor Robert Stack, best known for playing Eliot Ness in the TV series "The Untouchables", born.
1921 - Sir Johannes (Jo) Bjelke-Peterson, former premier of Queensland, Australia, born.
1929 - Marshal Wyatt Earp died; with his brothers he defeated the Clanton brothers at the legendary 1881 gunfight at the O.K. Corral.
1935 - In a plebiscite, the Saar region voted for incorporation into Germany.
1941 - Irish author James Joyce, whose works included the masterpiece "Ulysses", died.

1953 - In the so-called "Doctors' Plot" in the Soviet Union. Tass said nine "terrorist doctors" had been arrested for hastening the deaths of politburo members by falsifying diagnoses and prescribing harmful treatments.
1963 - Sylvanus Olympio, president of the Republic of Togo, was killed in a successful army coup led by Gnassingbe Eyadema.
1972 - In Ghana, a military coup by Colonel I.K. Acheampong deposed the civilian prime minister, Dr K.A. Busia, who was in London for medical treatment.
1976 - Britain applied for credit of almost one billion pounds sterling from the International Monetary Fund.
1978 - Former U.S. Vice-President Hubert Humphrey died.
1981 - UN-sponsored Conference on Namibia in Geneva failed to agree ceasefire and implementation of a plan for Namibia's independence.
1982 - 77 people died in an air crash in the Potomac River, Washington, D.C.
1994 - Italian Prime Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi resigned, opening the way for general elections to replace Italy's corruption-stained parliament.
